article.articleText: Red Cross is an internationally- connected foundation, which works for the general welfare of all. In 1864, Jean- Henri Dunant worked to this organization as a relief society for all. Through his efforts, Dunant received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1901, with the Red Cross following in 1917, 1944, 1963. The name Red Crescent, adopted in 1906 at the insistence of the Ottoman Empire, is used in Muslim countries. Originally purposed for a battlefield hospital, Red Cross has now expanded beyond casualty care into more wider categories such as prevention of human suffering. Red Cross operates in a duality of both peacetime and wartime. In wartime, it mediates with POW camps to provide relief and assist the prisoners. Its peacetime methods include aiding victims of disasters, maintaining blood banks, and providing complementary health care. Its mission includes the service of humanity, impartiality, and neutrality. Through their central hub in Genva, Red Cross continues to provide benevolent aid through national organization running subsidiary community programs. Clara Barton, "Lady of the Light", found Red Cross in 1881; Congress chartered it in 1900. It runs the world's largest donor service. Ever since WWII, Red Cross has greatly expanded into many areas. Many countries such as Hungary, Somalia, Rwanda owe the Red Cross for extensive refuge shelter and mediating for ethnic conflicts around the world. For example, during the Korean War, the International Red Cross mediated the first exchange of prisoners and sick combatants. Many people, who have suffered from natural disasters, around the world have been aided in great lengths with Red Cross.

The Birth of an Organization

May 21, 1881

Clara Barton and associates establish the American Red Cross.

Red Cross aids thousands of earthquake and fire victims in Tokyo and Yokohama, Japan.

Adoption of Values

October 8, 1965

Red Cross Movement adopts its Seven Fundamental Principles: Humanity, Impartiality, Neutrality, Independence, Voluntary Service, Unity and Universality.

HIV Testing

March 1985

Immediately after the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) licenses the first test to detect the antibody to HIV on March 3rd, Red Cross Blood Services regions begin testing all newly donated blood.
